content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Original and fun.

I reaffirm my approval from 4 months ago that was based on a very different version of this puzzle. The puzzle was good back then and it is has just gotten better and better over the months.

This is one of the things I absolutely love about Codingame. I've never met Rafarafa and I might never meet Rafarafa IRL, but I know A LOT about Rafarafa just from observing the tremendous diligence put into this puzzle. Great work!

Nice puzzle.
You could also add DFS in the tag's list, it's working fine with it too.
Isn't it weird that it still has two approvals from like 4 months ago? I'd assume it did reset once you put the contribution in private mode.

After adding @Timinator's suggestion the code was running so much faster than I decided to add three more tests. They all run under < 2secs in python.

Also updated n from 20 to 40.

The first time around, I didn't know Dijkstra's Algorithm and your new test cases would have made this puzzle extremely difficult for me. My old algorithm doesn't even come close to being fast enough. Having now read about and learned Dijkstra's Algorithm, this puzzle became pretty straightforward. Overall, I find the puzzle that much more powerful now with a very specific learning objective.

New things:

- Simplified statement (with a more detailed example now)
- Increased the maximum value of n from 10 to 20
- Added three tests, one for n = 15 and two for n = 20
- Difficulty from medium to hard (since this is just a bit harder than the labelled hard blunder-2) https://www.codingame.com/training/hard/blunder-episode-2
- Added tags (same as blunder-2)
- New solution
- Double checked performance, everything should take < 1.5 sec in python.

The generator can also be found here: https://github.com/daxida/CodinGame-contributions/tree/main/grid-climbing
I'm going to put this back on private until I figure out the Dijkstra's approach that 5DN1L is talking about. Maybe I can rework the difficulty depending on that.

Would add more tags, like BFS

What for rule c_1 < c_2 < ...  Wouldn't it be the same in the end with mixed costs order? For first impression it would be.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Well done!  Good coverage on the test cases.  Nice optimization aspect.

Very nice puzzle.  I see there was some discussion about speed a few months ago.  I'm using Python and my times are less than 325 ms for N=10.  I thought the optimization part of the puzzle was a nice feature and I enjoyed the little mental push it forced upon me. Are you sure you don't want to go higher than N=10?  I think you could push N a bit higher and still be a "medium" puzzle.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Interesting puzzle, the description is clear and the difficulty level is adequate.
Added a picture and some detail for the first example. I think this is pretty much it's final form, but let me know if you have any suggestions.
I hope you received enough feedback from the community to improve your contribution. Once you have made the necessary updates, publish your contribution!
gud
is there any mention about the grid(i, j) is between 0 and 9?

updates:
- Added tests for N up to 10. 
- Added a new solution (the previous one only worked for N up to 6)

Now some more efficiency is required to pass the last tests.

Constraints section:
* Do you mean "satisfy" instead of "verify"?
* Please also state the lower bound of n in the second constraint.

Stub generator
* Please add a write statement.

Thanks.

Well I tried to consistently reach <5secs in python for n = 7 to no avail. With the semi-random generator that I was using (the same used for the last 4 tests), I was getting 10 secs on average varying from 0.5 secs to 30 secs.

But if someone wants to give it a try and manages to do it please let me know ! This for instance, would take me 30 secs:
7
2 7 12 17 21 25
1013061
0170440
2033336
0406521
2004430
4002510
4301615

Fun puzzle.

If 27 is the right answer for your example with n = 7, my current solution can find the result in ~0.002s on CG (I am using PHP)
Fixed everything, thanks as usual :thumbsup:
one question about N=6 test, (0,0)->(1,1)->(5,5), the cost should be (0+2)+(0+14)=16, am I miss something?

One tiny spelling issue:

In this last part:

...the costs of moving an amount equal to d is the integer...

I believe "costs" should be "cost".

For my solution I yes, I never used the inequalities. It did feel more 'natural' when making the puzzle, as in moving two squares right would at least 'costs' you moving a square right etc. I'm not entirely sure on how it affects the puzzle.

As for the BFS tag, apparently other users have managed without BFS and I want to check out if I'll change the puzzle once I've managed to find their solutions.
I can see you are using BFS in your sample solution. Dijkstra's and BFS are basically the same. Dijkstra is a variant of BFS using priority_queue whereas BFS using a queue
:o Looks like a bug.
Mind sending your solution? Either here or by PM if you don't want other people seeing it.

Certainly, but I'm not sure it is a good practice to copy/paste a code here.
I sent it in PM.
I would have approved it again anyway :D

Yeah, I checked my solution again and I'm at 462 and 300ms for N=10. 

The thing is not only do I not know how it will fare for other languages, but also that, if I recall correctly, the limit is at 1s (?) and for n=11 my solution was extremely close to that (900ms on average).

I added the generator in comments to the bottom of my solution so you can experiment with it. If you think that n=11 is doable in reasonable time (let's say under 500ms), then I'll give it a go again.

Also, fixed the typo, thanks.

My experience has been that the timeout limit is actually somewhere between 5s and 6s.  I have a puzzle submitted right now that I need between 3 and 3.8 seconds to solve my toughest test case.

I'm for sure no expert on various languages.  However, you and I are both using Python and I'm under the impression that Python is on the slow side.

I ran my code about 30 times against different N=11 puzzles and the worst time I had was 770 ms. Many of the times were in the 600s and several in the mid 500s. I ran my code a bunch against different N=13 puzzles and never went over 3 seconds.

I'm going to give you an approval no matter where N ends up as I thoroughly enjoyed your puzzle.  However, I'm going to ask @5DN1L to comment on our speed conversation as I'm less than 2 years on CG and I am no expert on CG guidelines.

I used Dijkstra's algorithm to solve the puzzle. It took around 7 ms to solve the last pair of test and validator.

It does seem that grids of greater sizes are doable within the CG time limit. Now it depends on the author to decide whether to include such grids in the test cases or not. After all, some puzzles are created with the intention to cover aspects other than optimisation.

Also, I have no idea what the exact CG time limit is. I would consider 1 second* as an appropriate soft limit in setting the test cases with the aim of minimising the chances that it becomes impossible to solve a puzzle using slower programming languages.

* (in Python probably, as it is one of the most popular language used here?)
Thank you! I will be out of touch for a while learning Dijkstra's algorithm.

Previously I had explicitly stated that 0 <= grid(i, j) < 10, but it's redundant with the first sentence "grid of digits".

You are not factoring grid(0,0)=6 in your computation. The final result is 6 + what you wrote.
but then in test 1 it should be 6+1=7?

In test 1 the solution follows this path:
X..
X..
.XX
ok I understand now

fix a bug in my solution, now can pass all.
fun puzzle!

@5DN1L - would you mind commenting on the speed conversation I have been having with @Rafarafa above. I'm reasonably new to CG and I would benefit tremendously from your wisdom when it comes to speed considerations for CG puzzles.

Just saw another one:
Input section
* Please change [[N]] to [[n]] for consistency.

Thanks Rafarafa.

@Timinator I'll take a look.
Fixed, thanks. I'll keep an eye for your answer.

That seems to be the correct answer :thumbsup: 
I have no idea about how PHP's speed fares compare to python, but from browsing here at codingame I had the impression that PHP was a bit slower so wow...
May I ask how you did it? Just some pointers so I can give it a try again.

Right now you discard adding a point when the cost is bigger than the current min to the endpoint, what should get you the biggest boost would be to also discard adding a point when you previously reached that point (any point not just the endpoint) with a lower cost, if you did, the current path can't be the best path.

I tried to add your filtering of the next possible positions with the square centered, even with pre-computing all the squares I couldn't find a way to implement it that wasn't resulting in a slow down of the execution.

Pre-computing the costs to move from any (i, j) to any (i',j') is also something I already use and that should probably help you.

Sorry for the late response. I implemented your idea and now I can reach N = 10 in decent time (for N = 11 I'm at 1.6s average).
I went back to the original N = 7 I posted and now it's around 0.02s, I still have work to do to reach your 0.002s. I save some points that I shouldn't and make some prints to visualize the solutions that I could remove, but other than that you are right that any other heuristic that I've tried (discarding some points based on geometry etc.) results in a slowdown :(.

I also wanted to find a better way of creating grids with special path patterns since atm they are quite restrained unless I manually write them (like in the firsts tests with 0 and 9).
